title: 103_s882
content: The "Family Farm Retirement Equity Act of 1993" allows for the rollover of gain from the sale of farm assets into asset rollover accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Family Farm Retirement Equity Act of 1993" permits taxpayers with qualified net farm gain from selling a qualified farm asset to defer recognition of gain by contributing to asset rollover accounts, similar to individual retirement plans. The "Family Farm Retirement Equity Act of 1993" allows taxpayers to defer gain recognition by contributing to asset rollover accounts, similar to individual retirement plans. Contributions are not deductible, and there is an aggregate contribution limit of $500,000 ($250,000 for married individuals) for all accounts established during a qualified period. The individual (and spouse) must have assets exceeding $100,000 in individual retirement plans. Annual contribution limitations apply to asset rollover accounts, with a maximum contribution based on qualified net farm gain or $10,000 multiplied by the number of years as a qualified farmer. Married couples filing jointly have specific rules for contributions. For asset rollover accounts, contribution limits are based on qualified net farm gain or $20,000 for each year the taxpayer's spouse is a qualified farmer. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the preceding taxable year if made on account of that year and before the deadline for filing the tax return. The term 'qualified farm asset' refers to assets used by a qualified farmer in farming business. A 'qualified farmer' is defined as a taxpayer who actively participated in farming for at least 5 years before disposing of a qualified farm asset. In the context of qualified farm assets, ownership of a trade or business by the taxpayer or spouse for 5 years is required. Material participation is determined by meeting specific criteria. Rollover contributions are limited to asset rollover accounts, and distribution follows specific rules. Individual reporting of qualified contributions is mandatory. Individuals making contributions to asset rollover accounts or receiving amounts from them must report information on their tax return as required by the Secretary. Penalties for non-compliance are outlined in section 6693(b). Contributions to these accounts are not deductible according to section 219(d) of the Internal Revenue Code. Contributions to asset rollover accounts are not deductible under section 219(d) of the Internal Revenue Code. Excess contributions to these accounts are subject to penalties as outlined in section 4973 of the Code. The term 'excess contribution' refers to the amount contributed to an account for the taxable year exceeding the allowable contribution limit under section 1034A. Conforming amendments are made to section 4973 of the Internal Revenue Code to include asset rollover accounts. Technical amendments are also outlined in section 408(a) of the Code. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including defining individual retirement accounts and qualified contributions under section 1034A. Section 6693 is also amended to include references to section 1034A. Additionally, the table of sections is updated to include a new item related to section 1034A. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include a new section 1034A allowing rollover of gain on sale of farm assets into an asset rollover account. Effective for sales and exchanges after the enactment of this Act.
